'John Charles FrÃ©mont' or 'Fremont' (January 21, 1813 â July 13, 1890) was
an American military officer, explorer, and politician who became the first
candidate of the anti-slavery Republican Party for the office of President of
the United States. Dictionary of American Biography, pp.
19, 22 During the 1840s, that era's penny press accorded FrÃ©mont the
sobriquet The Pathfinder. Historians call him The Great Pathfinder. Allan
Nevins, ''FrÃ©mont, the West's Greatest Adventurer: Being a Biography from
Certain Hitherto Unpublished Sources of General John C. FrÃ©mont, Together with
His Wife, Jessie Benton FrÃ©mont, and Some Account of the Period of Expansion
which Found a Brilliant Leader in the Pathfinder'' (1928

FrÃ©mont, a Major in the U.S. Army, implemented the Bear Flag Republic in 1846.
During the Mexican American War, FrÃ©mont served as military Governor of
California, however, he was courtmartialed for mutiny and insubordination.
President Polk commuted his sentence for his military service. FrÃ©mont retired
from military service and settled in California after leading a fourth
expedition, which cost ten lives, seeking a rail route over the mountains
around the 38th parallel in the winter of 1849. FrÃ©mont was soon bogged down
with lawsuits over land claims between the dispossessions of various land
owners during the Mexican-American War, and the explosion of Forty-Niners
immigrating during the California Gold Rush. These cases were settled by the
U.S. Supreme Court where FrÃ©mont was allowed to keep his property. FrÃ©mont
acquired massive wealth during the California Gold Rush. FrÃ©mont became one of
the first two U.S. Senators elected from the new state California in 1850. He
was the first presidential candidate of the new Republican Party, carrying most
of the North. He lost the 1856 presidential election to Democrat James Buchanan
when Know-Nothings split the vote and Democrats warned his election would lead
to civil war.

During the American Civil War he was given command of Department of the West by
President Abraham Lincoln. Although FrÃ©mont had successes during his brief
tenure as Commander of the Western Armies, he ran his department autocratically,
and made hasty decisions without consulting Washington D.C. or President
Lincoln. After FrÃ©mont's emancipation edict that freed slaves in his district,
he was relieved of his command by President Lincoln for insubordination. In
1861, FrÃ©mont was the first commanding Union general who recognized an "iron
will" to fight in Brigadier General Ulysses S. Grant and promoted him commander
of Cairo. After the Civil War, FrÃ©mont's wealth declined after investing heavily
and purchasing an unsuccessful Pacific Railroad in 1866. FrÃ©mont served as
Governor of Arizona appointed by President Rutherford B. Hayes and served from
1878 to 1881. FrÃ©mont, retired from politics and financially destitute, died in
New York in 1890.

Historians portray FrÃ©mont as controversial, impetuous, and contradictory. Some
scholars regard him as a military hero of significant accomplishment, while
others view him as a failure who repeatedly defeated his own best purposes. The
keys to FrÃ©mont's character and personality may lie in his being born out of
wedlock, ambitious drive for success, self-justification, and passive-aggressive
behavior. Andrew Rolle, "Exploring an Explorer: California, Psychohistory,
and John C. Fremont," Southern California Quarterly, March 1994, Vol. 76#1 pp
85â98 Andrew F. Rolle, John Charles Fremont: Character As Destiny
(1991)
